description: It is a skin infection caused by fungi. Symptoms include itching, skin rashes, and nodal skin eruptions.
An immune system reaction to foreign substances such as pollen, dust, or food. Causes sneezing, itching, and rashes.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease occurs when stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn and indigestion.
A liver condition where bile flow is reduced or blocked, causing yellowing of the skin and fatigue.
An adverse response to a medication, ranging from mild rashes to severe, life-threatening anaphylaxis.
Sores that develop on the lining of the stomach, upper small intestine, or esophagus. Causes abdominal pain.
Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome, caused by HIV, leading to a severe failure of the immune system.
A metabolic disorder causing high blood sugar due to insulin problems. Types include Type 1 and Type 2.
Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, typically from an infection, causing vomiting and diarrhea.
A condition of consistently high blood pressure, which can lead to heart disease and stroke if untreated.
A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, often severe headaches with nausea and sensitivity to light.
A degenerative condition of the discs and joints in the neck, causing pain and stiffness.
A sudden sensation of spinning, usually triggered by specific changes in head position.
A yellowing of the skin and eyes caused by high levels of bilirubin, often due to liver dysfunction.
A life-threatening mosquito-borne blood disease caused by a Plasmodium parasite. Symptoms include fever and chills.
A highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy, blister-like rash, fever, and fatigue.
A mosquito-borne viral disease causing high fever, severe headache, pain, and a characteristic rash.
A bacterial infection spread through contaminated food or water, causing high fever and digestive distress.
A highly contagious liver infection caused by the HAV virus, spread through ingestion of contaminated substances.
A serious liver infection caused by the HBV virus, spread through blood and other body fluids.
A liver infection caused by the HCV virus, often chronic, spread primarily through contact with infected blood.
A serious liver disease that only occurs in people already infected with Hepatitis B.
A liver disease caused by the HEV virus, primarily spread through contaminated drinking water.
Liver inflammation caused by excessive consumption of alcohol.
A potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs, caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, causing a runny nose, sore throat, and cough.
An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus.
Hemorrhoids (swollen veins in the anus and lower rectum) that include both internal and external types.
Occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, often by a blood clot, damaging the heart muscle.
Enlarged, twisted veins, most commonly appearing in the legs and feet due to faulty valves.
A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to fatigue and weight gain.
Overactivity of the thyroid gland, resulting in excessive hormone production and speeding up body metabolism.
A condition characterized by an abnormally low level of blood sugar, causing shakiness, sweating, and confusion.
The most common form of arthritis, involving wear-and-tear damage to a joint's cartilage.
Inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age.
A sensation of feeling off balance, as if you or your surroundings are spinning.
A skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells, causing pimples.
An infection in any part of the urinary system, most commonly the bladder and urethra, causing painful urination.
A skin disease that causes a rash with itchy, scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, and scalp.
A common and highly contagious skin infection that causes red sores, mainly in infants and children.
A condition in which a person's airways become inflamed, narrow, and swell, producing extra mucus, making breathing difficult.
Heart conditions caused by high blood pressure, including heart failure and thickened heart muscle.
Inflammation of the nasal passages and sinuses, causing congestion, facial pain, and mucus production.
A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior.
A hereditary disorder causing severe damage to the lungs, digestive system, and other organs, due to thick mucus buildup.
Late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and alcoholism.
A type of inflammatory bowel disease causing chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, leading to abdominal pain and diarrhea.
An inflammatory bowel disease that causes long-lasting inflammation and sores in the digestive tract.
A gradual loss of kidney function over time, which can lead to a buildup of waste in the body.
An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, causing painful swelling and can lead to bone erosion and joint deformity.
A form of arthritis characterized by severe pain, redness, and tenderness in joints, often the big toe, due to uric acid crystal buildup.
A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing fatigue.
A cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and lymphatic system.
A cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the body's germ-fighting network.
Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.
A condition where the arteries become narrowed and hardened due to a buildup of plaque around the artery wall.
A blood circulation disorder that causes the blood vessels outside of your heart and brain to narrow, block, or spasm.
Inflammation of the gallbladder, often due to gallstones blocking the cystic duct, causing severe abdominal pain.
The process of forming stones in the kidney, bladder, and/or urethra (urinary tract).
A kidney disorder that causes your body to excrete too much protein in your urine.
A serious mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally, involving hallucinations, delusions, and disordered thinking.
A mental health condition causing extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania) and lows (depression).
A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with daily activities.
A disorder characterized by unreasonable thoughts and fears (obsessions) that lead to compulsive behaviors.
A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest, affecting how you feel and think.
A type of generalized seizure that affects the entire brain, involving stiffening of the body and repeated jerks.
Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, also known as pink eye.
An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum (the middle ear), common in children.
Inflammation of the tonsils, two oval-shaped pads of tissue at the back of the throat, causing sore throat and difficulty swallowing.
Often called 'mono,' it is an infectious disease usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, leading to fatigue and fever.
A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system — your nose, throat, and lungs — commonly called the flu.
A childhood infection caused by a virus, now preventable by vaccine. Serious for small children, characterized by a red, blotchy rash.
A viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands, causing puffy cheeks and a swollen jaw.
A contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. Also called German measles.
A highly contagious respiratory tract infection, known for a severe hacking cough followed by a high-pitched intake of breath.
A serious bacterial infection that causes painful muscle stiffness and lockjaw, often entering the body through a wound.
Inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord.
A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement, causing tremors, stiffness, and slowness.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, disrupting communication between brain and body.
A progressive disorder that causes brain cells to waste away (degenerate) and die, leading to continuous decline in memory and mental function.
A clouding of the normally clear lens of the eye, leading to blurry vision and eventual vision loss.
A group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often caused by abnormally high pressure in the eye.
An eye disease that can blur the sharp, central vision needed for activities like reading, caused by damage to the macula.
A common sexually transmitted infection (STI) that may not cause symptoms but can lead to serious reproductive problems.
A sexually transmitted infection (STI) that can cause infection in the genitals, rectum, and throat.
A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that starts as a painless sore and progresses in stages.
A common sexually transmitted infection (STI) marked by genital pain, sores, and blisters caused by the herpes simplex virus.
An itchy skin condition caused by a tiny burrowing mite called Sarcoptes scabiei, leading to intense itching.
An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread to humans through the bite of infected blacklegged ticks.
A highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy, blister-like rash, fever, and fatigue.
A viral infection that causes a painful rash, caused by the same virus that causes chickenpox (varicella-zoster virus).
A deadly virus spread to people from the saliva of infected animals, usually through a bite.
A rare but severe, often fatal illness in humans, caused by the Ebola virus, leading to fever and bleeding.
A mosquito-borne virus that typically causes mild fever and rash, but can cause severe birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.
A disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, leading to respiratory illness with symptoms ranging from mild to fatal.
Severe acute respiratory syndrome, a viral respiratory illness caused by a coronavirus.
Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, a viral respiratory illness caused by a coronavirus.
A contagious, disfiguring, and often deadly disease caused by the variola virus, now eradicated through vaccination.
A viral disease that affects the nervous system and can cause paralysis, now largely eradicated through vaccination.
A bacterial disease causing severe diarrhea and dehydration, usually spread in contaminated water.
